description: From Middle English busshel, from Old French boissel, from boisse, a grain measure based on Gaulish *bostyā (“handful”), from Proto-Celtic *bostā (“palm, fist”) (compare Breton boz (“hollow of the hand”), Old Irish bas), from Proto-Indo-European *gwost-, *gwosdʰ- (“branch”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A dry measure, containing four pecks, eight gallons, or thirty-two quarts.
examples: The quarter, bushel, and peck are nearly universal measures of corn.

entries.meaning: A vessel of the capacity of a bushel, used in measuring; a bushel measure.
A quantity that fills a bushel measure.
examples: a heap containing ten bushels of apples

entries.meaning: (UK) The iron lining in the nave of a wheel.

verbs.description: bushel (third-person singular simple present bushels, present participle busheling or bushelling, simple past and past participle busheled or bushelled)

entries.meaning: (US, tailoring, transitive, intransitive) To mend or repair clothes.
To pack grain, hops, etc. into bushel measures.
